verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:1
verses.text: Church History of Eusebius, Book VII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:2
verses.text: Introduction.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:3
verses.text: In this seventh book of the Church History, the great bishop of Alexandria, Dionysius, shall again assist us by his own words; relating the several affairs of his time in the epistles which he has left.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:4
verses.text: I will begin with them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:5
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:6
verses.text: —The Wickedness of Decius and Gallus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:7
verses.text: When Decius had reigned not quite two years, he was slain with his children, and Gallus succeeded him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:8
verses.text: At this time Origen died, being sixty-nine years of age.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:9
verses.text: Dionysius, writing to Hermammon, speaks as follows of Gallus:  "Gallus neither recognized the wickedness of Decius, nor considered what had destroyed him; but stumbled on the same stone, though it lay before his eyes.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:10
verses.text: For when his reign was prosperous and affairs were proceeding according to his mind, he attacked the holy men who were interceding with God for his peace and welfare.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:11
verses.text: Therefore with them he persecuted also their prayers in his behalf".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 1:12
verses.text: So much concerning him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 2:2
verses.text: —The Bishops of Rome in those Times.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 2:3
verses.text: Cornelius, having held the episcopate in the city of Rome about three years, was succeeded by Lucius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 2:4
verses.text: He died in less than eight months, and transmitted his office to Stephen.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 2:5
verses.text: Dionysius wrote to him the first of his letters on baptism, as no small controversy had arisen as to whether those who had turned from any heresy should be purified by baptism.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 2:6
verses.text: For the ancient custom prevailed in regard to such, that they should receive only the laying on of hands with prayers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 3:2
verses.text: —Cyprian, and the Bishops with him, first taught that it was necessary to purify by Baptism those converted from Heresy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 3:3
verses.text: First of all, Cyprian, pastor of the parish of Carthage, maintained that they should not be received except they had been purified from their error by baptism.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 3:4
verses.text: But Stephen considering it unnecessary to add any innovation contrary to the tradition which had been held from the beginning, was very indignant at this.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 4:2
verses.text: —The Epistles which Dionysius wrote on this Subject.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 4:3
verses.text: Dionysius, therefore, having communicated with him extensively on this question by letter, finally showed him that since the persecution had abated, the churches everywhere had rejected the novelty of Novatus, and were at peace among themselves.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 4:4
verses.text: He writes as follows:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:2
verses.text: —The Peace following the Persecution.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:3
verses.text: "But know now, my brethren, that all the churches throughout the East and beyond, which formerly were divided, have become united.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:4
verses.text: And all the bishops everywhere are of one mind, and rejoice greatly in the peace which has come beyond expectation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:5
verses.text: Thus Demetrianus in Antioch, Theoctistus in Caesarea, Mazabanes in aelia, Marinus in Tyre (Alexander having fallen asleep), Heliodorus in Laodicea (Thelymidres being dead), Helenus in Tarsus, and all the churches of Cilicia, Firmilianus, and all Cappadocia.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:6
verses.text: I have named only the more illustrious bishops, that I may not make my epistle too long and my words too burdensome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:7
verses.text: And all Syria, and Arabia to which you send help when needed, and whither you have just written, Mesopotamia, Pontus, Bithynia, and in short all everywhere are rejoicing and glorifying God for the unanimity and brotherly love".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:8
verses.text: Thus far Dionysius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:9
verses.text: But Stephen, having filled his office two years, was succeeded by Xystus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:10
verses.text: Dionysius wrote him a second epistle on baptism, in which he shows him at the same time the opinion and judgment of Stephen and the other bishops, and speaks in this manner of Stephen:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:11
verses.text: "He therefore had written previously concerning Helenus and Firmilianus, and all those in Cilicia and Cappadocia and Galatia and the neighboring nations, saying that he would not commune with them for this same cause; namely, that they re-baptized heretics.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:12
verses.text: But consider the importance of the matter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:13
verses.text: For truly in the largest synods of the bishops, as I learn, decrees have been passed on this subject, that those coming over from heresies should be instructed, and then should be washed and cleansed from the filth of the old and impure leaven.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:14
verses.text: And I wrote entreating him concerning all these things".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:15
verses.text: Further on he says:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:16
verses.text: "I wrote also, at first in few words, recently in many, to our beloved fellow-presbyters, Dionysius and Philemon, who formerly had held the same opinion as Stephen, and had written to me on the same matters".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 5:17
verses.text: So much in regard to the above-mentioned controversy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 6:2
verses.text: —The Heresy of Sabellius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 6:3
verses.text: He refers also in the same letter to the heretical teachings of Sabellius, which were in his time becoming prominent, and says:  "For concerning the doctrine now agitated in Ptolemais of Pentapolis,—which is impious and marked by great blasphemy against the Almighty God, the Father, and our Lord Jesus Christ, and contains much unbelief respecting his Only Begotten Son and the first-born of every creature, the Word which became man, and a want of perception of the Holy Spirit,—as there came to me communications from both sides and brethren discussing the matter, I wrote certain letters treating the subject as instructively as, by the help.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 6:4
verses.text: of God, I was able.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 6:5
verses.text: Of these I send thee copies".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:2
verses.text: —The Abominable Error of the Heretics; the Divine Vision of Dionysius; and the Ecclesiastical Canon which he received.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:3
verses.text: In the third epistle on baptism which this same Dionysius wrote to Philemon, the Roman presbyter, he relates the following: "But I examined the works and traditions of the heretics, defiling my mind for a little time with their abominable opinions, but receiving this benefit from them, that I refuted them by myself, and detested them all the more.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:4
verses.text: And when a certain brother among the presbyters restrained me, fearing that I should be carried away with the filth of their wickedness (for it would defile my soul),—in which also, as I perceived, he spoke the truth,—a vision sent from God came and strengthened me.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:5
verses.text: And the word which came to me commanded me, saying distinctly, 'Read everything which thou canst take in hand, for thou art able to correct and prove all; and this has been to thee from the beginning the cause of thy faith.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:6
verses.text: ' I received the vision as agreeing with the apostolic word, which says to them that are stronger, 'Be skillful money-changers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:8
verses.text: Then after saying some things concerning all the heresies he adds: "I received this rule and ordinance from our blessed father, Heraclas.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:9
verses.text: For those who came over from heresies, although they had apostatized from the Church,—or rather had not apostatized, but seemed to meet with them, yet were charged with resorting to some false teacher,—when he had expelled them from the Church he did not receive them back, though they entreated for it, until they had publicly reported all things which they had heard from their adversaries; but then he received them without requiring of them another baptism.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:10
verses.text: For they had formerly received the Holy Spirit from him".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:11
verses.text: Again, after treating the question thoroughly, he adds: "I have learned also that this is not a novel practice introduced in Africa alone, but that even long ago in the times of the bishops before us this opinion has been adopted in the most populous churches, and in synods of the brethren in Iconium and Synnada, and by many others.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:12
verses.text: To overturn their counsels and throw them into strife and contention, I cannot endure.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:13
verses.text: For it is said, 'Thou shalt not remove thy neighbor's landmark, which thy fathers have set.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:15
verses.text: His fourth epistle on baptism was written to Dionysius of Rome, who was then a presbyter, but not long after received the episcopate of that church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:16
verses.text: It is evident from what is stated of him by Dionysius of Alexandria, that he also was a learned and admirable man.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 7:17
verses.text: Among other things he writes to him as follows concerning Novatus:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 8:2
verses.text: —The Heterodoxy of Novatus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 8:3
verses.text: "For with good reason do we feel hatred toward Novatian, who has sundered the Church and drawn some of the brethren into impiety and blasphemy, and has introduced impious teaching concerning God, and has calumniated our most compassionate Lord Jesus Christ as unmerciful.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 8:4
verses.text: And besides all this he rejects the holy baptism, and overturns the faith and confession which precede it, and entirely banishes from them the Holy Ghost, if indeed there was any hope that he would remain or return to them".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:2
verses.text: —The Ungodly Baptism of the Heretics.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:3
verses.text: His fifth epistle was written to Xystus, bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:4
verses.text: In this, after saying much against the heretics, he relates a certain occurrence of his time as follows: "For truly, brother, I am in need of counsel, and I ask thy judgment concerning a certain matter which has come to me, fearing that I may be in error.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:5
verses.text: For one of the brethren that assemble, who has long been considered a believer, and who, before my ordination, and I think before the appointment of the blessed Heraclas, was a member of the congregation, was present with those who were recently baptized.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:6
verses.text: And when he heard the questions and answers, he came to me weeping, and bewailing himself; and falling at my feet he acknowledged and protested that the baptism with which he had been baptized among the heretics was not of this character, nor in any respect like this, because it was full of impiety and blasphemy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:7
verses.text: And he said that his soul was now pierced with sorrow, and that he had not confidence to lift his eyes to God, because he had set out from those impious words and deeds.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:8
verses.text: And on this account he besought that he might receive this most perfect purification, and reception and grace.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:9
verses.text: But I did not dare to do this; and said that his long communion was sufficient for this.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:10
verses.text: For I should not dare to renew from the beginning one who had heard the giving of thanks and joined in repeating the Amen; who had stood by the table and had stretched forth his hands to receive the blessed food; and who had received it, and partaken for a long while of the body and blood of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:11
verses.text: But I exhorted him to be of good courage, and to approach the partaking of the saints with firm faith and good hope.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:12
verses.text: But he does not cease lamenting, and he shudders to approach the table, and scarcely, though entreated, does he dare to be present at the prayers".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:13
verses.text: Besides these there is also extant another epistle of the same man on baptism, addressed by him and his parish to Xystus and the church at Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:14
verses.text: In this he considers the question then agitated with extended argument.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:15
verses.text: And there is extant yet another after these, addressed to Dionysius of Rome, concerning Lucian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 9:16
verses.text: So much with reference to these.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:2
verses.text: —Valerian and the Persecution under him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:3
verses.text: Gallus and the other rulers, having held the government less than two years, were overthrown, and Valerian, with his son Gallienus, received the empire.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:4
verses.text: The circumstances which Dionysius relates of him we may learn from his epistle to Hermammon, in which he gives the following account:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:5
verses.text: "And in like manner it is revealed to John; 'For there was given to him,' he says, 'a mouth speaking great things and blasphemy; and there was given unto him authority and forty and two months.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:7
verses.text: It is wonderful that both of these things occurred under Valerian; and it is the more remarkable in this case when we consider his previous conduct, for he had been mild and friendly toward the men of God, for none of the emperors before him had treated them so kindly and favorably; and not even those who were said openly to be Christians received them with such manifest hospitality and friendliness as he did at the beginning of his reign.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:8
verses.text: For his entire house was filled with pious persons and was a church of God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:9
verses.text: But the teacher and ruler of the synagogue of the Magi from Egypt persuaded him to change his course, urging him to slay and persecute pure and holy men because they opposed and hindered the corrupt and abominable incantations.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:10
verses.text: For there are and there were men who, being present and being seen, though they only breathed and spoke, were able to scatter the counsels of the sinful demons.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:11
verses.text: And he induced him to practice initiations and abominable sorceries and to offer unacceptable sacrifices; to slay innumerable children and to sacrifice the offspring of unhappy fathers; to divide the bowels of new-born babes and to mutilate and cut to pieces the creatures of God, as if by such practices they could attain happiness".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:12
verses.text: He adds to this the following: "Splendid indeed were the thank-offerings which Macrianus brought them for the empire which was the object of his hopes.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:13
verses.text: He is said to have been formerly the emperor's general finance minister; yet he did nothing praiseworthy or of general benefit, but fell under the prophetic saying,.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:14
verses.text: 'Woe unto those who prophesy from their own heart and do not consider the general good.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:15
verses.text: ' For he did not perceive the general Providence, nor did he look for the judgment of Him who is before all, and through all, and over all.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:16
verses.text: Wherefore he became an enemy of his Catholic Church, and alienated and estranged himself from the compassion of God, and fled as far as possible from his salvation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:17
verses.text: In this he showed the truth of his own name".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:18
verses.text: And again, farther on he says: "For Valerian, being instigated to such acts by this man, was given over to insults and reproaches, according to what was said by Isaiah: 'They have chosen their own ways and their abominations in which their soul delighted; I also will choose their delusions and will render unto them their sins.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:20
verses.text: But this man madly desired the kingdom though unworthy of it, and being unable to put the royal garment on his crippled body, set forward his two sons to bear their father's sins.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:21
verses.text: For concerning them the declaration which God spoke was plain, 'Visiting the iniquities of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth generation of them that hate me.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:23
verses.text: For heaping on the heads of his sons his own evil desires, in which he had met with success, he wiped off upon them his own wickedness and hatred toward God".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 10:24
verses.text: Dionysius relates these things concerning Valerian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:2
verses.text: —The Events which happened at this Time to Dionysius and those in Egypt.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:3
verses.text: But as regards the persecution which prevailed so fiercely in his reign, and the sufferings which Dionysius with others endured on account of piety toward the God of the universe, his own words shall show, which he wrote in answer to Germanus, a contemporary bishop who was endeavoring to slander him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:4
verses.text: His statement is as follows:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:5
verses.text: "Truly I am in danger of falling into great folly and stupidity through being forced to relate the wonderful providence of God toward us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:6
verses.text: But since it is said that 'it is good to keep close the secret of a king, but it is honorable to reveal the works of God,' I will join issue with the violence of Germanus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:7
verses.text: I went not alone to aemilianus; but my fellow-presbyter, Maximus, and the deacons Faustus, Eusebius, and Chaeremon, and a brother who was present from Rome, went with me.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:8
verses.text: But aemilianus did not at first say to me: 'Hold no assemblies;' for this was superfluous to him, and the last thing to one who was seeking to accomplish the first.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:9
verses.text: For he was not concerned about our assembling, but that we ourselves should not be Christians.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:10
verses.text: And he commanded me to give this up; supposing if I turned from it, the others also would follow me.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:11
verses.text: But I answered him, neither unsuitably nor in many words: 'We must obey God rather than men.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:12
verses.text: ' And I testified openly that I worshiped the one only God, and no other; and that I would not turn from this nor would I ever cease to be a Christian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:13
verses.text: Thereupon he commanded us to go to a village near the desert, called Cephro.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:14
verses.text: But listen to the very words which were spoken on both sides, as they were recorded: "Dionysius, Faustus, Maximus, Marcellus, and Chaeremon being arraigned, aemilianus the prefect said:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:15
verses.text: 'I have reasoned verbally with you concerning the clemency which our rulers have shown to you; for they have given you the opportunity to save yourselves, if you will turn to that which is according to nature, and worship the gods that preserve their empire, and forget those that are contrary to nature.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:16
verses.text: What then do you say to this? For I do not think that you will be ungrateful for their kindness, since they would turn you to a better course.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:18
verses.text: Dionysius replied: 'Not all people worship all gods; but each one those whom he approves.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:19
verses.text: We therefore reverence and worship the one God, the Maker of all; who hath given the empire to the divinely favored and august Valerian and Gallienus; and we pray to him continually for their empire that it may remain unshaken.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:21
verses.text: aemilianus, the prefect, said to them: 'But who forbids you to worship him, if he is a god, together with those who are gods by nature.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:22
verses.text: For ye have been commanded to reverence the gods, and the gods whom all know.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:23
verses.text: ' Dionysius answered:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:24
verses.text: 'We worship no other.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:25
verses.text: ' aemilianus, the prefect, said to them: 'I see that you are at once ungrateful, and insensible to the kindness of our sovereigns.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:26
verses.text: Wherefore ye shall not remain in this city.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:27
verses.text: But ye shall be sent into the regions of Libya, to a place called Cephro.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:28
verses.text: For I have chosen this place at the command of our sovereigns, and it shall by no means be permitted you or any others, either to hold assemblies, or to enter into the so called cemeteries.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:29
verses.text: But if any one shall be seen without the place which I have commanded, or be found in any assembly, he will bring peril on himself.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:30
verses.text: For suitable punishment shall not fail.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:31
verses.text: Go, therefore where ye have been ordered.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:32
verses.text: '  "And he hastened me away, though I was sick, not granting even a day's respite.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:33
verses.text: What opportunity then did I have, either to hold assemblies, or not to hold them?".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:34
verses.text: Farther on he says: "But through the help of the Lord we did not give up the open assembly.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:35
verses.text: But I called together the more diligently those who were in the city, as if I were with them; being, so to speak, 'absent in body but present in spirit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:36
verses.text: ' But in Cephro a large church gathered with us of the brethren that followed us from the city, and those that joined us from Egypt; and there 'God opened unto us a door for the Word.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:38
verses.text: At first we were persecuted and stoned; but afterwards not a few of the heathen forsook the idols and turned to God.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:39
verses.text: For until this time they had not heard the Word, since it was then first sown by us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:40
verses.text: And as if God had brought us to them for this purpose, when we had performed this ministry he transferred us to another place.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:41
verses.text: For aemilianus, as it appeared, desired to transport us to rougher and more Libyan-like places; so he commanded them to assemble from all quarters in Mareotis, and assigned to them different villages throughout the country.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:42
verses.text: But he ordered us to be placed nearer the highway that we might be seized first.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:43
verses.text: For evidently he arranged and prepared matters so that whenever he wished to seize us he could take all of us without difficulty.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:44
verses.text: When I was first ordered to go to Cephro I did not know where the place was, and had scarcely ever heard the name; yet I went readily and cheerfully.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:45
verses.text: But when I was told that I was to remove to the district of Colluthion, those who were present know how I was affected.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:46
verses.text: For here I will accuse myself.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:47
verses.text: At first I was grieved and greatly disturbed; for though these places were better known and more familiar to us, yet the country was said to be destitute of brethren and of men of character, and to be exposed to the annoyances of travelers and incursions of robbers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:48
verses.text: But I was comforted when the brethren reminded me that it was nearer the city, and that while Cephro afforded us much intercourse with the brethren from Egypt, so that we were able to extend the Church more widely, as this place was nearer the city we should enjoy more frequently the sight of those who were truly beloved and most closely related and dearest to us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:49
verses.text: For they would come and remain, and special meetings could be held, as in the more remote suburbs.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:50
verses.text: And thus it turned out".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:51
verses.text: After other matters he writes again as follows of the things which happened to him:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:52
verses.text: "Germanus indeed boasts of many confessions.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:53
verses.text: He can speak forsooth of many adversities which he himself has endured.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:54
verses.text: But is he able to reckon up as many as we can, of sentences, confiscations, proscriptions, plundering of goods, loss of dignities, contempt of worldly glory, disregard for the flatteries of governors and of councilors, and patient endurance of the threats of opponents, of outcries, of perils and persecutions, and wandering and distress, and all kinds of tribulation, such as came upon me under Decius and Sabinus, and such as continue even now under aemilianus? But where has Germanus been seen? And what account is there of him?.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:55
verses.text: But I turn from this great folly into which I am falling on account of Germanus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:56
verses.text: And for the same reason I desist from giving to the brethren who know it an account of everything which took place".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:57
verses.text: The same writer also in the epistle to Domitius and Didymus mentions some particulars of the persecution as follows: "As our people are many and unknown to you, it would be superfluous to give their names; but understand that men and women, young and old, maidens and matrons, soldiers and civilians, of every race and age, some by scourging and fire, others by the sword, have conquered in the strife and received their crowns.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:58
verses.text: But in the case of some a very long time was not sufficient to make them appear acceptable to the Lord; as, indeed, it seems also in my own case, that sufficient time has not yet elapsed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:59
verses.text: Wherefore he has retained me for the time which he knows to be fitting, saying, 'In an acceptable time have I heard thee, and in a day of salvation have I helped thee.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:61
verses.text: For as you have inquired of our affairs and desire us to tell you how we are situated, you have heard fully that when we—that is, myself and Gaius and Faustus and Peter and Paul—were led away as prisoners by a centurion and magistrates, with their soldiers and servants, certain persons from Mareotis came and dragged us away by force, as we were unwilling to follow them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:62
verses.text: But now I and Gaius and Peter are alone, deprived of the other brethren, and shut up in a desert and dry place in Libya, three days' journey from Paraetonium".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:63
verses.text: He says farther on: "The presbyters, Maximus, Dioscorus, Demetrius, and Lucius concealed themselves in the city, and visited the brethren secretly; for Faustinus and Aquila, who are more prominent in the world, are wandering in Egypt.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:64
verses.text: But the deacons, Faustus, Eusebius, and Chaeremon, have survived those who died in the pestilence.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:65
verses.text: Eusebius is one whom God has strengthened and endowed from the first to fulfill energetically the ministrations for the imprisoned confessors, and to attend to the dangerous task of preparing for burial the bodies of the perfected and blessed martyrs.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:66
verses.text: For as I have said before, unto the present time the governor continues to put to death in a cruel manner those who are brought to trial.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:67
verses.text: And he destroys some with tortures, and wastes others away with imprisonment and bonds; and he suffers no one to go near them, and investigates whether any one does so.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:68
verses.text: Nevertheless God gives relief to the afflicted through the zeal and persistence of the brethren".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:69
verses.text: Thus far Dionysius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:70
verses.text: But it should be known that Eusebius, whom he calls a deacon, shortly afterward became bishop of the church of Laodicea in Syria; and Maximus, of whom he speaks as being then a presbyter, succeeded Dionysius himself as bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:71
verses.text: But the Faustus who was with him, and who at that time was distinguished for his confession, was preserved until the persecution in our day, when being very old and full of days, he closed his life by martyrdom, being beheaded.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 11:72
verses.text: But such are the things which happened at that time to Dionysius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 12:2
verses.text: —The Martyrs in Caesarea in Palestine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 12:3
verses.text: During the above-mentioned persecution under Valerian, three men in Caesarea in Palestine, being conspicuous in their confession of Christ, were adorned with divine martyrdom, becoming food for wild beasts.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 12:4
verses.text: One of them was called Priscus, another Malchus, and the name of the third was Alexander.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 12:5
verses.text: They say that these men, who lived in the country, acted at first in a cowardly manner, as if they were careless and thoughtless.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 12:6
verses.text: For when the opportunity was given to those who longed for the prize with heavenly desire, they treated it lightly, lest they should seize the Crown of martyrdom prematurely.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 12:7
verses.text: But having deliberated on the matter, they hastened to Caesarea, and went before the judge and met the end we have mentioned.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 12:8
verses.text: They relate that besides these, in the same persecution and the same city, a certain woman endured a similar conflict.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 12:9
verses.text: But it is reported that she belonged to the sect of Marcion.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:2
verses.text: —The Peace under Gallienus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:3
verses.text: Shortly after this Valerian was reduced to slavery by the barbarians, and his son having become sole ruler, conducted the government more prudently.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:4
verses.text: He immediately restrained the persecution against us by public proclamations, and directed the bishops to perform in freedom their customary duties, in a rescript which ran as follows:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:5
verses.text: "The Emperor Caesar Publius Licinius Gallienus, Pius, Felix, Augustus, to Dionysius, Pinnas, Demetrius, and the other bishops.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:6
verses.text: I have ordered the bounty of my gift to be declared through all the world, that they may depart from the places of religious worship.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:7
verses.text: And for this purpose you may use this copy of my rescript, that no one may molest you.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:8
verses.text: And this which you are now enabled lawfully to do, has already for a long time been conceded by me.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:9
verses.text: Therefore Aurelius Cyrenius, who is the chief administrator of affairs, will observe this ordinance which I have given".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:10
verses.text: I have given this in a translation from the Latin, that it may be more readily understood.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 13:11
verses.text: Another decree of his is extant addressed to other bishops, permitting them to take possession again of the so-called cemeteries.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 14:2
verses.text: —The Bishops that flourished at that Time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 14:3
verses.text: At that time Xystus was still presiding over the church of Rome, and Demetrianus, successor of Fabius, over the church of Antioch, and Firmilianus over that of Caesarea in Cappadocia; and besides these, Gregory and his brother Athenodorus, friends of Origen, were presiding over the churches in Pontus; and Theoctistus of Caesarea in Palestine having died, Domnus received the episcopate there.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 14:4
verses.text: He held it but a short time, and Theotecnus, our contemporary, succeeded him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 14:5
verses.text: He also was a member of Origen's school.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 14:6
verses.text: But in Jerusalem, after the death of Mazabanes, Hymenaeus, who has been celebrated among us for a great many years, succeeded to his seat.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:2
verses.text: —The Martyrdom of Marinus at Caesarea.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:3
verses.text: At this time, when the peace of the churches had been everywhere restored, Marinus in Caesarea in Palestine, who was honored for his military deeds, and illustrious by virtue of family and wealth, was beheaded for his testimony to Christ, on the following account.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:4
verses.text: The vine-branch is a certain mark of honor among the Romans, and those who obtain it become, they say, centurions.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:5
verses.text: A place being vacated, the order of succession called Marinus to this position.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:6
verses.text: But when he was about to receive the honor, another person came before the tribunal and claimed that it was not legal, according to the ancient laws, for him to receive the Roman dignity, as he was a Christian and did not sacrifice to the emperors; but that the office belonged rather to him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:7
verses.text: Thereupon the judge, whose name was Achaeus, being disturbed, first asked what opinion Marinus held.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:8
verses.text: And when he perceived that he continually confessed himself a Christian, he gave him three hours for reflection.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:9
verses.text: When he came out from the tribunal, Theotecnus, the bishop there, took him aside and conversed with him, and taking his hand led him into the church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:10
verses.text: And standing with him within, in the sanctuary, he raised his cloak a little, and pointed to the sword that hung by his side; and at the same time he placed before him the Scripture of the divine Gospels, and told him to choose which of the two he wished.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:11
verses.text: And without hesitation he reached forth his right hand, and took the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:12
verses.text: "Hold fast then," says Theotecnus to him, "hold fast to God, and strengthened by him mayest thou obtain what thou hast chosen, and go in peace".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:13
verses.text: Immediately on his return the herald cried out calling him to the tribunal, for the appointed time was already completed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 15:14
verses.text: And standing before the tribunal, and manifesting greater zeal for the faith, immediately, as he was, he was led away and finished his course by death.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 16:2
verses.text: —Story in Regard to Astyrius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 16:3
verses.text: Astyrius also is commemorated on account of his pious boldness in connection with this affair.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 16:4
verses.text: He was a Roman of senatorial rank, and in favor with the emperors, and well known to all on account of his noble birth and wealth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 16:5
verses.text: Being present at the martyr's death, he took his body away on his shoulder, and arraying him in a splendid and costly garment, prepared him for the grave in a magnificent manner, and gave him fitting burial.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 16:6
verses.text: The friends of this man, that remain to our day, relate many other facts concerning him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 17:2
verses.text: —The Signs at Paneas of the Great Might of our Saviour.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 17:3
verses.text: Among these is also the following wonder.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 17:4
verses.text: At Caesarea Philippi, which the Phoenicians call Paneas, springs are shown at the foot of the Mountain Panius, out of which the Jordan flows.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 17:5
verses.text: They say that on a certain feast day, a victim was thrown in, and that through the power of the demon it marvelously disappeared and that which happened was a famous wonder to those who were present.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 17:6
verses.text: Astyrius was once there when these things were done, and seeing the multitude astonished at the affair, he pitied their delusion; and looking up to heaven he supplicated the God over all through Christ, that he would rebuke the demon who deceived the people, and bring the men's delusion to an end.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 17:7
verses.text: And they say that when he had prayed thus, immediately the sacrifice floated on the surface of the fountain.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 17:8
verses.text: And thus the miracle departed; and no wonder was ever afterward performed at the place.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:2
verses.text: —The Statue which the Woman with an Issue of Blood erected.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:3
verses.text: Since I have mentioned this city I do not think it proper to omit an account which is worthy of record for posterity.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:4
verses.text: For they say that the woman with an issue of blood, who, as we learn from the sacred Gospel, received from our Saviour deliverance from her affliction, came from this place, and that her house is shown in the city, and that remarkable memorials of the kindness of the Saviour to her remain there.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:5
verses.text: For there stands upon an elevated stone, by the gates of her house, a brazen image of a woman kneeling, with her hands stretched out, as if she were praying.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:6
verses.text: Opposite this is another upright image of a man, made of the same material, clothed decently in a double cloak, and extending his hand toward the woman.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:7
verses.text: At his feet, beside the statue itself, is a certain strange plant, which climbs up to the hem of the brazen cloak, and is a remedy for all kinds of diseases.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:8
verses.text: They say that this statue is an image of Jesus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:9
verses.text: It has remained to our day, so that we ourselves also saw it when we were staying in the city.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 18:10
verses.text: Nor is it strange that those of the Gentiles who, of old, were benefited by our Saviour, should have done such things, since we have learned also that the likenesses of his apostles Paul and Peter, and of Christ himself, are preserved in paintings, the ancients being accustomed, as it is likely, according to a habit of the Gentiles, to pay this kind of honor indiscriminately to those regarded by them as deliverers.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 19:2
verses.text: —The Episcopal Chair of James.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 19:3
verses.text: The chair of James, who first received the episcopate of the church at Jerusalem from the Saviour himself and the apostles, and who, as the divine records show, was called a brother of Christ, has been preserved until now, the brethren who have followed him in succession there exhibiting clearly to all the reverence which both those of old times and those of our own day maintained and do maintain for holy men on account of their piety.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 19:4
verses.text: So much as to this matter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 20:2
verses.text: —The Festal Epistles of Dionysius, in which he also gives a Paschal Canon.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 20:3
verses.text: Dionysius, besides his epistles already mentioned, wrote at that time also his extant Festal Epistles, in which he uses words of panegyric respecting the passover feast.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 20:4
verses.text: He addressed one of these to Flavius, and another to Domitius and Didymus, in which he sets forth a canon of eight years, maintaining that it is not proper to observe the paschal feast until after the vernal equinox.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 20:5
verses.text: Besides these he sent another epistle to his fellow-presbyters in Alexandria, as well as various others to different persons while the persecution was still prevailing.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:2
verses.text: —The Occurrences at Alexandria.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:3
verses.text: Peace had but just been restored when he returned to Alexandria; but as sedition and war broke out again, rendering it impossible for him to oversee all the brethren, separated in different places by the insurrection, at the feast of the passover, as if he were still an exile from Alexandria, he addressed them again by letter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:4
verses.text: And in another festal epistle written later to Hierax, a bishop in Egypt, he mentions the sedition then prevailing in Alexandria, as follows:  "What wonder is it that it is difficult for me to communicate by letters with those who live far away, when it is beyond my power even to reason with myself, or to take counsel for my own life?.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:5
verses.text: Truly I need to send letters to those who are as my own bowels, dwelling in one home, and brethren of one soul, and citizens of the same church; but how to send them I cannot tell.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:6
verses.text: For it would be easier for one to go, not only beyond the limits of the province, but even from the East to the West, than from Alexandria to Alexandria itself.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:7
verses.text: For the very heart of the city is more intricate and impassable than that great and trackless desert which Israel traversed for two generations.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:8
verses.text: And our smooth and waveless harbors have become like the sea, divided and walled up, through which Israel drove and in whose highway the Egyptians were overwhelmed.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:9
verses.text: For often from the slaughters there committed they appear like the Red Sea.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:10
verses.text: And the river which flows by the city has sometimes seemed drier than the waterless desert, and more parched than that in which Israel, as they passed through it, so suffered for thirst, that they cried out against Moses, and the water flowed for them from the steep rock, through him who alone doeth wonders.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:11
verses.text: Again it has overflowed so greatly as to flood all the surrounding country, and the roads and the fields; threatening to bring back the deluge of water that occurred in the days of Noah.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:12
verses.text: And it flows along, polluted always with blood and slaughter and drownings, as it became for Pharaoh through the agency of Moses, when he changed it into blood, and it stank.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:13
verses.text: And what other water could purify the water which purifies everything? How could the ocean, so great and impassable for men, if poured into it, cleanse this bitter sea? Or how could the great river which flowed out of Eden, if it poured the four heads into which it is divided into the one of Geon, wash away this pollution?.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:14
verses.text: Or when can the air poisoned by these noxious exhalations become pure? For such vapors arise from the earth, and winds from the sea, and breezes from the river, and mists from the harbors, that the dews are, as it were, discharges from dead bodies putrefying in all the elements around us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:15
verses.text: Yet men wonder and cannot understand whence these continuous pestilences; whence these severe sicknesses; whence these deadly diseases of all kinds; whence this various and vast human destruction; why this great city no longer contains as many inhabitants, from tender infants to those most advanced in life, as it formerly contained of those whom it called hearty old men.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:16
verses.text: But the men from forty to seventy years of age were then so much more numerous that their number cannot now be filled out, even when those from fourteen to eighty years are enrolled and registered for the public allowance of food.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:17
verses.text: And the youngest in appearance have become, as it were, of equal age with those who formerly were the oldest.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 21:18
verses.text: But though they see the race of men thus constantly diminishing and wasting away, and though their complete destruction is increasing and advancing, they do not tremble".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:2
verses.text: —The Pestilence which came upon them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:3
verses.text: After these events a pestilential disease followed the war, and at the approach of the feast he wrote again to the brethren, describing the sufferings consequent upon this calamity.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:4
verses.text: "To other men the present might not seem to be a suitable time for a festival.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:5
verses.text: Nor indeed is this or any other time suitable for them; neither sorrowful times, nor even such as might be thought especially cheerful.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:6
verses.text: Now, indeed, everything is tears and every one is mourning, and wailings resound daily through the city because of the multitude of the dead and dying.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:7
verses.text: For as it was written of the firstborn of the Egyptians, so now 'there has arisen a great cry, for there is not a house where there is not one dead.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:8
verses.text: ' And would that this were all!.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:9
verses.text: For many terrible things have happened already.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:10
verses.text: First, they drove us out; and when alone, and persecuted, and put to death by all, even then we kept the feast.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:11
verses.text: And every place of affliction was to us a place of festival: field, desert, ship, inn, prison; but the perfected martyrs kept the most joyous festival of all, feasting in heaven.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:12
verses.text: After these things war and famine followed, which we endured in common with the heathen.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:13
verses.text: But we bore alone those things with which they afflicted us, and at the same time we experienced also the effects of what they inflicted upon and suffered from one another; and again, we rejoiced in the peace of Christ, which he gave to us alone.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:14
verses.text: "But after both we and they had enjoyed a very brief season of rest this pestilence assailed us; to them more dreadful than any dread, and more intolerable than any other calamity; and, as one of their own writers has said, the only thing which prevails over all hope.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:15
verses.text: But to us this was not so, but no less than the other things was it an exercise and probation.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:16
verses.text: For it did not keep aloof even from us, but the heathen it assailed more severely".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:17
verses.text: Farther on he adds:  "The most of our brethren were unsparing in their exceeding love and brotherly kindness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:18
verses.text: They held fast to each other and visited the sick fearlessly, and ministered to them continually, serving them in Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:19
verses.text: And they died with them most joyfully, taking the affliction of others, and drawing the sickness from their neighbors to themselves and willingly receiving their pains.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:20
verses.text: And many who cared for the sick and gave strength to others died themselves having transferred to themselves their death.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:21
verses.text: And the popular saying which always seems a mere expression of courtesy, they then made real in action, taking their departure as the others' 'offscouring.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:23
verses.text: "Truly the best of our brethren departed from life in this manner, including some presbyters and deacons and those of the people who had the highest reputation; so that this form of death, through the great piety and strong faith it exhibited, seemed to lack nothing of martyrdom.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:24
verses.text: And they took the bodies of the saints in their open hands and in their bosoms, and closed their eyes and their mouths; and they bore them away on their shoulders and laid them out; and they clung to them and embraced them; and they prepared them suitably with washings and garments.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:25
verses.text: And after a little they received like treatment themselves, for the survivors were continually following those who had gone before them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:26
verses.text: "But with the heathen everything was quite otherwise.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:27
verses.text: They deserted those who began to be sick, and fled from their dearest friends.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:28
verses.text: And they cast them out into the streets when they were half dead, and left the dead like refuse, unburied.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:29
verses.text: They shunned any participation or fellowship with death; which yet, with all their precautions, it was not easy for them to escape".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:30
verses.text: After this epistle, when peace had been restored to the city, he wrote another festal letter to the brethren in Egypt, and again several others besides this.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:31
verses.text: And there is also a certain one extant On the Sabbath, and another On Exercise.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 22:32
verses.text: Moreover, he wrote again an epistle to Hermammon and the brethren in Egypt, describing at length the wickedness of Decius and his successors, and mentioning the peace under Gallienus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:2
verses.text: —The Reign of Gallienus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:3
verses.text: But there is nothing like hearing his own words, which are as follows:  "Then he, having betrayed one of the emperors that preceded him, and made war on the other, perished with his whole family speedily and utterly.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:4
verses.text: But Gallienus was proclaimed and universally acknowledged at once an old emperor and a new, being before them and continuing after them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:5
verses.text: For according to the word spoken by the prophet Isaiah, 'Behold the things from the beginning have come to pass, and new things shall now arise.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:6
verses.text: ' For as a cloud passing over the sun's rays and obscuring them for a little time hides it and appears in its place; but when the cloud has passed by or is dissipated, the sun which had risen before appears again; so Macrianus who put himself forward and approached the existing empire of Gallienus, is not, since he never was.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:7
verses.text: But the other is just as he was.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:8
verses.text: And his kingdom, as if it had cast aside old age, and had been purified from the former wickedness, now blossoms out more vigorously, and is seen and heard farther, and extends in all directions".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:9
verses.text: He then indicates the time at which he wrote this in the following words:  "It occurs to me again to review the days of the imperial years.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:10
verses.text: For I perceive that those most impious men, though they have been famous, yet in a short time have become nameless.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 23:11
verses.text: But the holier and more godly prince, having passed the seventh year, is now completing the ninth, in which we shall keep the feast".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:2
verses.text: —Nepos and his Schism.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:3
verses.text: Besides all these the two books on the Promises were prepared by him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:4
verses.text: The occasion of these was Nepos, a bishop in Egypt, who taught that the promises to the holy men in the Divine Scriptures should be understood in a more Jewish manner, and that there would be a certain millennium of bodily luxury upon this earth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:5
verses.text: As he thought that he could establish his private opinion by the Revelation of John, he wrote a book on this subject, entitled Refutation of Allegorists.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:6
verses.text: Dionysius opposes this in his books on the Promises.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:7
verses.text: In the first he gives his own opinion of the dogma; and in the second he treats of the Revelation of John, and mentioning Nepos at the beginning, writes of him in this manner:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:8
verses.text: "But since they bring forward a certain work of Nepos, on which they rely confidently, as if it proved beyond dispute that there will be a reign of Christ upon earth, I confess that in many other respects I approve and love Nepos, for his faith and industry and diligence in the Scriptures, and for his extensive psalmody, with which many of the brethren are still delighted; and I hold him in the more reverence because he has gone to rest before us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:9
verses.text: But the truth should be loved and honored most of all.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:10
verses.text: And while we should praise and approve ungrudgingly what is said aright, we ought to examine and correct what does not seem to have been written soundly.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:11
verses.text: Were he present to state his opinion orally, mere unwritten discussion, persuading and reconciling those who are opposed by question and answer, would be sufficient.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:12
verses.text: But as some think his work very plausible, and as certain teachers regard the law and prophets as of no consequence, and do not follow the Gospels, and treat lightly the apostolic epistles, while they make promises as to the teaching of this work as if it were some great hidden mystery, and do not permit our simpler brethren to have any sublime and lofty thoughts concerning the glorious and truly divine appearing of our Lord, and our resurrection from the dead, and our being gathered together unto him, and made like him, but on the contrary lead them to hope for small and mortal things in the kingdom of God, and for things such as exist now,—since this is the case, it is necessary that we should dispute with our brother Nepos as if he were present".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:13
verses.text: Farther on he says:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:14
verses.text: "When I was in the district of Arsinoë, where, as you know, this doctrine has prevailed for a long time, so that schisms and apostasies of entire churches have resulted, I called together the presbyters and teachers of the brethren in the villages,—such brethren as wished being also present,—and I exhorted them to make a public examination of this question.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:15
verses.text: Accordingly when they brought me this book, as if it were a weapon and fortress impregnable, sitting with them from morning till evening for three successive days, I endeavored to correct what was written in it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:16
verses.text: And I rejoiced over the constancy, sincerity, docility, and intelligence of the brethren, as we considered in order and with moderation the questions and the difficulties and the points of agreement.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:17
verses.text: And we abstained from defending in every manner and contentiously the opinions which we had once held, unless they appeared to be correct.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:18
verses.text: Nor did we evade objections, but we endeavored as far as possible to hold to and confirm the things which lay before us, and if the reason given satisfied us, we were not ashamed to change our opinions and agree with others; but on the contrary, conscientiously and sincerely, and with hearts laid open before God, we accepted whatever was established by the proofs and teachings of the Holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:19
verses.text: And finally the author and mover of this teaching, who was called Coracion, in the hearing of all the brethren that were present, acknowledged and testified to us that he would no longer hold this opinion, nor discuss it, nor mention nor teach it, as he was fully convinced by the arguments against it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 24:20
verses.text: And some of the other brethren expressed their gratification at the conference, and at the spirit of conciliation and harmony which all had manifested".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:2
verses.text: —The Apocalypse of John.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:3
verses.text: Afterward he speaks in this manner of the Apocalypse of John.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:4
verses.text: "Some before us have set aside and rejected the book altogether, criticising it chapter by chapter, and pronouncing it without sense or argument, and maintaining that the title is fraudulent.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:5
verses.text: For they say that it is not the work of John, nor is it a revelation, because it is covered thickly and densely by a vail of obscurity.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:6
verses.text: And they affirm that none of the apostles, and none of the saints, nor any one in the Church is its author, but that Cerinthus, who founded the sect which was called after him the Cerinthian, desiring reputable authority for his fiction, prefixed the name.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:7
verses.text: For the doctrine which he taught was this: that the kingdom of Christ will be an earthly one.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:8
verses.text: And as he was himself devoted to the pleasures of the body and altogether sensual in his nature, he dreamed that that kingdom would consist in those things which he desired, namely, in the delights of the belly and of sexual passion; that is to say, in eating and drinking and marrying, and in festivals and sacrifices and the slaying of victims, under the guise of which he thought he could indulge his appetites with a better grace.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:9
verses.text: "But I could not venture to reject the book, as many brethren hold it in high esteem.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:10
verses.text: But I suppose that it is beyond my comprehension, and that there is a certain concealed and more wonderful meaning in every part.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:11
verses.text: For if I do not understand I suspect that a deeper sense lies beneath the words.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:12
verses.text: I do not measure and judge them by my own reason, but leaving the more to faith I regard them as too high for me to grasp.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:13
verses.text: And I do not reject what I cannot comprehend, but rather wonder because I do not understand it".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:14
verses.text: After this he examines the entire Book of Revelation, and having proved that it is impossible to understand it according to the literal sense, proceeds as follows:  "Having finished all the prophecy, so to speak, the prophet pronounces those blessed who shall observe it, and also himself.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:15
verses.text: For he says, 'Blessed is he that keepeth the words of the prophecy of this book, and I, John, who saw and heard these things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:17
verses.text: Therefore that he was called John, and that this book is the work of one John, I do not deny.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:18
verses.text: And I agree also that it is the work of a holy and inspired man.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:19
verses.text: But I cannot readily admit that he was the apostle, the son of Zebedee, the brother of James, by whom the Gospel of John and the Catholic Epistle were written.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:20
verses.text: For I judge from the character of both, and the forms of expression, and the entire execution of the book, that it is not his.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:21
verses.text: For the evangelist nowhere gives his name, or proclaims himself, either in the Gospel or Epistle".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:22
verses.text: Farther on he adds:  "But John never speaks as if referring to himself, or as if referring to another person.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:23
verses.text: But the author of the Apocalypse introduces himself at the very beginning: 'The Revelation of Jesus Christ, which he gave him to show unto his servants quickly; and he sent and signified it by his angel unto his servant John, who bare witness of the word of God and of his testimony, even of all things that he saw.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:25
verses.text: Then he writes also an epistle: 'John to the seven churches which are in Asia, grace be with you, and peace.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:26
verses.text: ' But the evangelist did not prefix his name even to the Catholic Epistle; but without introduction he begins with the mystery of the divine revelation itself: 'That which was from the beginning, which we have heard, which we have seen with our eyes.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:27
verses.text: ' For because of such a revelation the Lord also blessed Peter, saying, 'Blessed art thou, Simon Bar-Jonah, for flesh and blood hath not revealed it unto thee, but my heavenly Father.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:29
verses.text: But neither in the reputed second or third epistle of John, though they are very short, does the name John appear; but there is written the anonymous phrase, 'the elder.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:30
verses.text: ' But this author did not consider it sufficient to give his name once and to proceed with his work; but he takes it up again: 'I, John, who also am your brother and companion in tribulation, and in the kingdom and in the patience of Jesus Christ, was in the isle that is called Patmos for the Word of God and the testimony of Jesus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:31
verses.text: ' And toward the close he speaks thus: 'Blessed is he that keepeth the words of the prophecy of this book, and I, John, who saw and heard these things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:33
verses.text: "But that he who wrote these things was called John must be believed, as he says it; but who he was does not appear.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:34
verses.text: For he did not say, as often in the Gospel, that he was the beloved disciple of the Lord, or the one who lay on his breast, or the brother of James, or the eyewitness and hearer of the Lord.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:35
verses.text: For he would have spoken of these things if he had wished to show himself plainly.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:36
verses.text: But he says none of them; but speaks of himself as our brother and companion, and a witness of Jesus, and blessed because he had seen and heard the revelations.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:37
verses.text: But I am of the opinion that there were many with the same name as the apostle John, who, on account of their love for him, and because they admired and emulated him, and desired to be loved by the Lord as he was, took to themselves the same surname, as many of the children of the faithful are called Paul or Peter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:38
verses.text: For example, there is also another John, surnamed Mark, mentioned in the Acts of the Apostles, whom Barnabas and Paul took with them; of whom also it is said, 'And they had also John as their attendant.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:39
verses.text: ' But that it is he who wrote this, I would not say.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:40
verses.text: For it not written that he went with them into Asia, but, 'Now when Paul and his company set sail from Paphos, they came to Perga in Pamphylia and John departing from them returned to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:42
verses.text: But I think that he was some other one of those in Asia; as they say that there are two monuments in Ephesus, each bearing the name of John.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:43
verses.text: "And from the ideas, and from the words and their arrangement, it may be reasonably conjectured that this one is different from that one.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:44
verses.text: For the Gospel and Epistle agree with each other and begin in the same manner.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:45
verses.text: The one says, 'In the beginning was the Word'; the other, 'That which was from the beginning.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:46
verses.text: ' The one: 'And the Word was made flesh and dwelt among us, and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father'; the other says the same things slightly altered: 'Which we have heard, which we have seen with our eyes; which we have looked upon and our hands have handled of the Word of life,—and the life was manifested.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:48
verses.text: For he introduces these things at the beginning, maintaining them, as is evident from what follows, in opposition to those who said that the Lord had not come in the flesh.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:49
verses.text: Wherefore also he carefully adds, 'And we have seen and bear witness, and declare unto you the eternal life which was with the Father and was manifested unto us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:50
verses.text: That which we have seen and heard declare we unto you also.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:52
verses.text: He holds to this and does not digress from his subject, but discusses everything under the same heads and names some of which we will briefly mention.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:53
verses.text: Any one who examines carefully will find the phrases, 'the life,' 'the light,' 'turning from darkness,' frequently occurring in both; also continually, 'truth,' 'grace,' 'joy,' 'the flesh and blood of the Lord,' 'the judgment,' 'the forgiveness of sins,' 'the love of God toward us,' the 'commandment that we love one another,' that we should 'keep all the commandments'; the 'conviction of the world, of the Devil, of Anti-Christ,' the 'promise of the Holy Spirit,' the 'adoption of God,' the 'faith continually required of us,' 'the Father and the Son,' occur everywhere.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:54
verses.text: In fact, it is plainly to be seen that one and the same character marks the Gospel and the Epistle throughout.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:55
verses.text: But the Apocalypse is different from these writings and foreign to them; not touching, nor in the least bordering upon them; almost, so to speak, without even a syllable in common with them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:56
verses.text: Nay more, the Epistle—for I pass by the Gospel—does not mention nor does it contain any intimation of the Apocalypse, nor does the Apocalypse of the Epistle.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:57
verses.text: But Paul, in his epistles, gives some indication of his revelations, though he has not written them out by themselves.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:58
verses.text: "Moreover, it can also be shown that the diction of the Gospel and Epistle differs from that of the Apocalypse.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:59
verses.text: For they were written not only without error as regards the Greek language, but also with elegance in their expression, in their reasonings, and in their entire structure.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:60
verses.text: They are far indeed from betraying any barbarism or solecism, or any vulgarism whatever.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:61
verses.text: For the writer had, as it seems, both the requisites of discourse,—that is, the gift of knowledge and the gift of expression,—as the Lord had bestowed them both upon him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:62
verses.text: I do not deny that the other writer saw a revelation and received knowledge and prophecy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:63
verses.text: I perceive, however, that his dialect and language are not accurate Greek, but that he uses barbarous idioms, and, in some places, solecisms.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 25:64
verses.text: It is unnecessary to point these out here, for I would not have any one think that I have said these things in a spirit of ridicule, for I have said what I have only with the purpose of showing clearly the difference between the writings".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.
