verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 26:2
verses.text: —The Epistles of Dionysius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 26:3
verses.text: Besides these, many other epistles of Dionysius are extant, as those against Sabellius, addressed to Ammon, bishop of the church of Bernice, and one to Telesphorus, and one to Euphranor, and again another to Ammon and Euporus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 26:4
verses.text: He wrote also four other books on the same subject, which he addressed to his namesake Dionysius, in Rome.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 26:5
verses.text: Besides these many of his epistles are with us, and large books written in epistolary form, as those on Nature, addressed to the young man Timothy, and one on Temptations, which he also dedicated to Euphranor.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 26:6
verses.text: Moreover, in a letter to Basilides, bishop of the parishes in Pentapolis, he says that he had written an exposition of the beginning of Ecclesiastes.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 26:7
verses.text: And he has left us also various letters addressed to this same person.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 26:8
verses.text: Thus much Dionysius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 26:9
verses.text: But our account of these matters being now completed, permit us to show to posterity the character of our own age.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 27:2
verses.text: —Paul of Samosata, and the Heresy introduced by him at Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 27:3
verses.text: After Xystus had presided over the church of Rome for eleven years, Dionysius, namesake of him of Alexandria, succeeded him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 27:4
verses.text: About the same time Demetrianus died in Antioch, and Paul of Samosata received that episcopate.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 27:5
verses.text: As he held, contrary to the teaching of the Church, low and degraded views of Christ, namely, that in his nature he was a common man, Dionysius of Alexandria was entreated to come to the synod.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 27:6
verses.text: But being unable to come on account of age and physical weakness, he gave his opinion on the subject under consideration by letter.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 27:7
verses.text: But all the other pastors of the churches from all directions, made haste to assemble at Antioch, as against a despoiler of the flock of Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 28:2
verses.text: —The Illustrious Bishops of that Time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 28:3
verses.text: Of these, the most eminent were Firmilianus, bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia; the brothers Gregory and Athenodorus, pastors of the churches in Pontus; Helenus of the parish of Tarsus, and Nicomas of Iconium; moreover, Hymenaeus, of the church of Jerusalem, and Theotecnus of the neighboring church of Caesarea; and besides these Maximus, who presided in a distinguished manner over the brethren in Bostra.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 28:4
verses.text: If any should count them up he could not fail to note a great many others, besides presbyters and deacons, who were at that time assembled for the same cause in the above-mentioned city.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 28:5
verses.text: But these were the most illustrious.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 28:6
verses.text: When all of these assembled at different times and frequently to consider these matters, the arguments and questions were discussed at every meeting; the adherents of the Samosatian endeavoring to cover and conceal his heterodoxy, and the others striving zealously to lay bare and make manifest his heresy and blasphemy against Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 28:7
verses.text: Meanwhile, Dionysius died in the twelfth year of the reign of Gallienus, having held the episcopate of Alexandria for seventeen years, and Maximus succeeded him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 28:8
verses.text: Gallienus after a reign of fifteen years was succeeded by Claudius, who in two years delivered the government to Aurelian.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 29:2
verses.text: —Paul, having been refuted by Malchion, a Presbyter from the Sophists, was excommunicated.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 29:3
verses.text: During his reign a final synod composed of a great many bishops was held, and the leader of heresy in Antioch was detected, and his false doctrine clearly shown before all, and he was excommunicated from the Catholic Church under heaven.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 29:4
verses.text: Malchion especially drew him out of his hiding-place and refuted him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 29:5
verses.text: He was a man learned in other respects, and principal of the sophist school of Grecian learning in Antioch; yet on account of the superior nobility of his faith in Christ he had been made a presbyter of that parish.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 29:6
verses.text: This man, having conducted a discussion with him, which was taken down by stenographers and which we know is still extant, was alone able to detect the man who dissembled and deceived the others.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:2
verses.text: —The Epistle of the Bishops against Paul.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:3
verses.text: The pastors who had assembled about this matter, prepared by common consent an epistle addressed to Dionysius, bishop of Rome, and Maximus of Alexandria, and sent it to all the provinces.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:4
verses.text: In this they make manifest to all their own zeal and the perverse error of Paul, and the arguments and discussions which they had with him, and show the entire life and conduct of the man.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:5
verses.text: It may be well to put on record at the present time the following extracts from their writing:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:6
verses.text: "To Dionysius and Maximus, and to all our fellow-ministers throughout the world, bishops, presbyters, and deacons, and to the whole Catholic Church under heaven, Helenus, Hymenaeus, Theophilus, Theotecnus, Maximus, Proclus, Nicomas, aelianus, Paul, Bolanus, Protogenes, Hierax, Eutychius, Theodorus, Malchion, and Lucius, and all the others who dwell with us in the neighboring cities and nations, bishops, presbyters, and deacons, and the churches of God, greeting to the beloved brethren in the Lord".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:7
verses.text: A little farther on they proceed thus: "We sent for and called many of the bishops from a distance to relieve us from this deadly doctrine; as Dionysius of Alexandria and Firmilianus of Cappadocia, those blessed men.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:8
verses.text: The first of these not considering the author of this delusion worthy to be addressed, sent a letter to Antioch, not written to him, but to the entire parish, of which we give a copy below.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:9
verses.text: But Firmilianus came twice and condemned his innovations, as we who were present know and testify, and many others understand.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:10
verses.text: But as he promised to change his opinions, he believed him and hoped that without any reproach to the Word what was necessary would be done.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:11
verses.text: So he delayed the matter, being deceived by him who denied even his own God and Lord, and had not kept the faith which he formerly held.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:12
verses.text: And now Firmilianus was again on his way to Antioch, and had come as far as Tarsus because he had learned by experience his God-denying wickedness.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:13
verses.text: But while we, having come together, were calling for him and awaiting his arrival, he died".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:14
verses.text: After other things they describe as follows the manner of life which he led:.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:15
verses.text: "Whereas he has departed from the rule of faith, and has turned aside after base and spurious teachings, it is not necessary,—since he is without,—that we should pass judgment upon his practices: as for instance in that although formerly destitute and poor, and having received no wealth from his fathers, nor made anything by trade or business, he now possesses abundant wealth through his iniquities and sacrilegious acts, and through those things which he extorts from the brethren, depriving the injured of their rights and promising to assist them for reward, yet deceiving them, and plundering those who in their trouble are ready to give that they may obtain reconciliation with their oppressors, 'supposing that gain is godliness';—.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:16
verses.text: or in that he is haughty, and is puffed up, and assumes worldly dignities, preferring to be called ducenarius rather than bishop; and struts in the market-places, reading letters and reciting them as he walks in public, attended by a body-guard, with a multitude preceding and following him, so that the faith is envied and hated on account of his pride and haughtiness of heart;—.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:17
verses.text: or in that he practices chicanery in ecclesiastical assemblies, contrives to glorify himself, and deceive with appearances, and astonish the minds of the simple, preparing for himself a tribunal and lofty throne,—not like a disciple of Christ,—and possessing a 'secretum,'—like the rulers of the world,—and so calling it, and striking his thigh with his hand, and stamping on the tribunal with his feet;—or in that he rebukes and insults those who do not applaud, and shake their handkerchiefs as in the theaters, and shout and leap about like the men and women that are stationed around him, and hear him in this unbecoming manner, but who listen reverently and orderly as in the house of God;—or in that he violently and coarsely assails in public the expounders of the Word that have departed this life, and magnifies himself, not as a bishop, but as a sophist and juggler,.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:18
verses.text: and stops the psalms to our Lord Jesus Christ, as being the modern productions of modern men, and trains women to sing psalms to himself in the midst of the church on the great day of the passover, which any one might shudder to hear, and persuades the bishops and presbyters of the neighboring districts and cities who fawn upon him, to advance the same ideas in their discourses to the people.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:19
verses.text: For to anticipate something of what we shall presently write, he is unwilling to acknowledge that the Son of God has come down from heaven.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:20
verses.text: And this is not a mere assertion, but it is abundantly proved from the records which we have sent you; and not least where he says 'Jesus Christ is from below.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:21
verses.text: ' But those singing to him and extolling him among the people say that their impious teacher has come down an angel from heaven.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:22
verses.text: And he does not forbid such things; but the arrogant man is even present when they are uttered.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:23
verses.text: And there are the women, the 'subintroductae,' as the people of Antioch call them, belonging to him and to the presbyters and deacons that are with him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:24
verses.text: Although he knows and has convicted these men, yet he connives at this and their other incurable sins, in order that they may be bound to him, and through fear for themselves may not dare to accuse him for his wicked words and deeds.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:25
verses.text: But he has also made them rich; on which account he is loved and admired by those who covet such things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:26
verses.text: We know, beloved, that the bishop and all the clergy should be an example to the people of all good works.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:27
verses.text: And we are not ignorant how many have fallen or incurred suspicion, through the women whom they have thus brought in.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:28
verses.text: So that even if we should allow that he commits no sinful act, yet he ought to avoid the suspicion which arises from such a thing, lest he scandalize some one, or lead others to imitate him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:29
verses.text: For how can he reprove or admonish another not to be too familiar with women,—lest he fall, as it is written,—when he has himself sent one away already, and now has two with him, blooming and beautiful, and takes them with him wherever he goes, and at the same time lives in luxury and surfeiting?.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:30
verses.text: Because of these things all mourn and lament by themselves; but they so fear his tyranny and power, that they dare not accuse him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:31
verses.text: But as we have said, while one might call the man to account for this conduct, if he held the Catholic doctrine and was numbered with us, since he has scorned the mystery and struts about in the abominable heresy of Artemas (for why should we not mention his father?), we think it unnecessary to demand of him an explanation of these things".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:32
verses.text: Afterwards, at the close of the epistle, they add these words:  "Therefore we have been compelled to excommunicate him, since he sets himself against God, and refuses to obey; and to appoint in his place another bishop for the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:33
verses.text: By divine direction, as we believe, we have appointed Domnus, who is adorned with all the qualities becoming in a bishop, and who is a son of the blessed Demetrianus, who formerly presided in a distinguished manner over the same parish.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:34
verses.text: We have informed you of this that you may write to him, and may receive letters of communion from him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:35
verses.text: But let this man write to Artemas; and let those who think as Artemas does, communicate with him".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:36
verses.text: As Paul had fallen from the episcopate, as well as from the orthodox faith, Domnus, as has been said, became bishop of the church at Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:37
verses.text: But as Paul refused to surrender the church building, the Emperor Aurelian was petitioned; and he decided the matter most equitably, ordering the building to be given to those to whom the bishops of Italy and of the city of Rome should adjudge it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:38
verses.text: Thus this man was driven out of the church, with extreme disgrace, by the worldly power.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:39
verses.text: Such was Aurelian's treatment of us at that time; but in the course of his reign he changed his mind in regard to us, and was moved by certain advisers to institute a persecution against us.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:40
verses.text: And there was great talk about this on every side.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:41
verses.text: But as he was about to do it, and was, so to speak, in the very act of signing the decrees against us, the divine judgment came upon him and restrained him at the very verge of his undertaking, showing in a manner that all could see clearly, that the rulers of this world can never find an opportunity against the churches of Christ, except the hand that defends them permits it, in divine and heavenly judgment, for the sake of discipline and correction, at such times as it sees best.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:42
verses.text: After a reign of six years, Aurelian was succeeded by Probus.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:43
verses.text: He reigned for the same number of years, and Carus, with his sons, Carinus and Numerianus, succeeded him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:44
verses.text: After they had reigned less than three years the government devolved on Diocletian, and those associated with him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:45
verses.text: Under them took place the persecution of our time, and the destruction of the churches connected with it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 30:46
verses.text: Shortly before this, Dionysius, bishop of Rome, after holding office for nine years, died, and was succeeded by Felix.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 31:2
verses.text: —The Perversive Heresy of the Manicheans which began at this Time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 31:3
verses.text: At this time, the madman, named from his demoniacal heresy, armed himself in the perversion of his reason, as the devil, Satan, who himself fights against God, put him forward to the destruction of many.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 31:4
verses.text: He was a barbarian in life, both in word and deed; and in his nature demoniacal and insane.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 31:5
verses.text: In consequence of this he sought to pose as Christ, and being puffed up in his madness, he proclaimed himself the Paraclete and the very Holy Spirit; and afterwards, like Christ, he chose twelve disciples as partners of his new doctrine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 31:6
verses.text: And he patched together false and godless doctrines collected from a multitude of long-extinct impieties, and swept them, like a deadly poison, from Persia to our part of the world.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 31:7
verses.text: From him the impious name of the Manicheans is still prevalent among many.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 31:8
verses.text: Such was the foundation of this "knowledge falsely so-called," which sprang up in those times.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:2
verses.text: —The Distinguished Ecclesiasticsof our Day, and which of them survived until the Destruction of the Churches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:3
verses.text: At this time, Felix, having presided over the church of Rome for five years, was succeeded by Eutychianus, but he in less than ten months left the position to Caius, who lived in our day.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:4
verses.text: He held it about fifteen years, and was in turn succeeded by Marcellinus, who was overtaken by the persecution.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:5
verses.text: About the same time Timaeus received the episcopate of Antioch after Domnus, and Cyril, who lived in our day, succeeded him.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:6
verses.text: In his time we became acquainted with Dorotheus, a man of learning among those of his day, who was honored with the office of presbyter in Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:7
verses.text: He was a lover of the beautiful in divine things, and devoted himself to the Hebrew language, so that he read the Hebrew Scriptures with facility.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:8
verses.text: He belonged to those who were especially liberal, and was not unacquainted with Grecian propaedeutics.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:9
verses.text: Besides this he was a eunuch, having been so from his very birth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:10
verses.text: On this account, as if it were a miracle, the emperor took him into his family, and honored him by placing him over the purple dye-works at Tyre.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:11
verses.text: We have heard him expound the Scriptures wisely in the Church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:12
verses.text: After Cyril, Tyrannus received the episcopate of the parish of Antioch.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:13
verses.text: In his time occurred the destruction of the churches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:14
verses.text: Eusebius, who had come from the city of Alexandria, ruled the parishes of Laodicea after Socrates.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:15
verses.text: The occasion of his removal thither was the affair of Paul.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:16
verses.text: He went on this account to Syria, and was restrained from returning home by those there who were zealous in divine things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:17
verses.text: Among our contemporaries he was a beautiful example of religion, as is readily seen from the words of Dionysius which we have quoted.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:18
verses.text: Anatolius was appointed his successor; one good man, as they say, following another.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:19
verses.text: He also was an Alexandrian by birth.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:20
verses.text: In learning and skill in Greek philosophy, such as arithmetic and geometry, astronomy, and dialectics in general, as well as in the theory of physics, he stood first among the ablest men of our time, and he was also at the head in rhetorical science.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:21
verses.text: It is reported that for this reason he was requested by the citizens of Alexandria to establish there a school of Aristotelian philosophy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:22
verses.text: They relate of him many other eminent deeds during the siege of the Pyrucheium in Alexandria, on account of which he was especially honored by all those in high office; but I will give the following only as an example.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:23
verses.text: They say that bread had failed the besieged, so that it was more difficult to withstand the famine than the enemy outside; but he being present provided for them in this manner.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:24
verses.text: As the other part of the city was allied with the Roman army, and therefore was not under siege, Anatolius sent for Eusebius,—for he was still there before his transfer to Syria, and was among those who were not besieged, and possessed, moreover, a great reputation and a renowned name which had reached even the Roman general,—and he informed him of those who were perishing in the siege from famine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:25
verses.text: When he learned this he requested the Roman commander as the greatest possible favor, to grant safety to deserters from the enemy.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:26
verses.text: Having obtained his request, he communicated it to Anatolius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:27
verses.text: As soon as he received the message he convened the senate of Alexandria, and at first proposed that all should come to a reconciliation with the Romans.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:28
verses.text: But when he perceived that they were angered by this advice, he said, "But I do not think you will oppose me, if I counsel you to send the supernumeraries and those who are in nowise useful to us, as old women and children and old men, outside the gates, to go wherever they may please.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:29
verses.text: For why should we retain for no purpose these who must at any rate soon die? and why should we destroy with hunger those who are crippled and maimed in body, when we ought to provide only for men and youth, and to distribute the necessary bread among those who are needed for the garrison of the city?".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:30
verses.text: With such arguments he persuaded the assembly, and rising first he gave his vote that the entire multitude, whether of men or women, who were not needful for the army, should depart from the city, because if they remained and unnecessarily continued in the city, there would be for them no hope of safety, but they would perish with famine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:31
verses.text: As all the others in the senate agreed to this, he saved almost all the besieged.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:32
verses.text: He provided that first, those belonging to the church, and afterwards, of the others in the city, those of every age should escape, not only the classes included in the decree, but, under cover of these, a multitude of others, secretly clothed in women's garments; and through his management they went out of the gates by night and escaped to the Roman camp.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:33
verses.text: There Eusebius, like a father and physician, received all of them, wasted away through the long siege, and restored them by every kind of prudence and care.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:34
verses.text: The church of Laodicea was honored by two such pastors in succession, who, in the providence of God, came after the aforesaid war from Alexandria to that city.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:35
verses.text: Anatolius did not write very many works; but in such as have come down to us we can discern his eloquence and erudition.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:36
verses.text: In these he states particularly his opinions on the passover.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:37
verses.text: It seems important to give here the following extracts from them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:38
verses.text: From the Paschal Canons of Anatolius.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:39
verses.text: "There is then in the first year the new moon of the first month, which is the beginning of every cycle of nineteen years, on the twenty-sixth day of the Egyptian Phamenoth; but according to the months of the Macedonians, the twenty-second day of Dystrus, or, as the Romans would say, the eleventh before the Kalends of April.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:40
verses.text: On the said twenty-sixth of Phamenoth, the sun is found not only entered on the first segment, but already passing through the fourth day in it.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:41
verses.text: They are accustomed to call this segment the first dodecatomorion, and the equinox, and the beginning of months, and the head of the cycle, and the starting-point of the planetary circuit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:42
verses.text: But they call the one preceding this the last of months, and the twelfth segment, and the final dodecatomorion, and the end of the planetary circuit.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:43
verses.text: Wherefore we maintain that those who place the first month in it, and determine by it the fourteenth of the passover, commit no slight or common blunder.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:44
verses.text: And this is not an opinion of our own; but it was known to the Jews of old, even before Christ, and was carefully observed by them.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:45
verses.text: This may be learned from what is said by Philo, Josephus, and Musaeus; and not only by them, but also by those yet more ancient, the two Agathobuli, surnamed 'Masters,' and the famous Aristobulus, who was chosen among the seventy interpreters of the sacred and divine Hebrew Scriptures by Ptolemy Philadelphus and his father, and who also dedicated his exegetical books on the law of Moses to the same kings.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:46
verses.text: These writers, explaining questions in regard to the Exodus, say that all alike should sacrifice the passover offerings after the vernal equinox, in the middle of the first month.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:47
verses.text: But this occurs while the sun is passing through the first segment of the solar, or as some of them have styled it, the zodiacal circle.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:48
verses.text: Aristobulus adds that it is necessary for the feast of the passover, that not only the sun should pass through the equinoctial segment, but the moon also.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:49
verses.text: For as there are two equinoctial segments, the vernal and the autumnal, directly opposite each other, and as the day of the passover was appointed on the fourteenth of the month, beginning with the evening, the moon will hold a position diametrically opposite the sun, as may be seen in full moons; and the sun will be in the segment of the vernal equinox, and of necessity the moon in that of the autumnal.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:50
verses.text: I know that many other things have been said by them, some of them probable, and some approaching absolute demonstration, by which they endeavor to prove that it is altogether necessary to keep the passover and the feast of unleavened bread after the equinox.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:51
verses.text: But I refrain from demanding this sort of demonstration for matters from which the veil of the Mosaic law has been removed, so that now at length with uncovered face we continually behold as in a glass Christ and the teachings and sufferings of Christ.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:52
verses.text: But that with the Hebrews the first month was near the equinox, the teachings also of the Book of Enoch show".

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:53
verses.text: The same writer has also left the Institutes of Arithmetic, in ten books, and other evidences of his experience and proficiency in divine things.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:54
verses.text: Theotecnus, bishop of Caesarea in Palestine, first ordained him as bishop, designing to make him his successor in his own parish after his death.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:55
verses.text: And for a short time both of them presided over the same church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:56
verses.text: But the synod which was held to consider Paul's case called him to Antioch, and as he passed through the city of Laodicea, Eusebius being dead, he was detained by the brethren there.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:57
verses.text: And after Anatolius had departed this life, the last bishop of that parish before the persecution was Stephen, who was admired by many for his knowledge of philosophy and other Greek learning.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:58
verses.text: But he was not equally devoted to the divine faith, as the progress of the persecution manifested; for it showed that he was a cowardly and unmanly dissembler rather than a true philosopher.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:59
verses.text: But this did not seriously injure the church, for Theodotus restored their affairs, being straightway made bishop of that parish by God himself, the Saviour of all.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:60
verses.text: He justified by his deeds both his lordly name and his office of bishop.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:61
verses.text: For he excelled in the medical art for bodies, and in the healing art for souls.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:62
verses.text: Nor did any other man equal him in kindness, sincerity, sympathy, and zeal in helping such as needed his aid.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:63
verses.text: He was also greatly devoted to divine learning.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:64
verses.text: Such an one was he.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:65
verses.text: In Caesarea in Palestine, Agapius succeeded Theotecnus, who had most zealously performed the duties of his episcopate.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:66
verses.text: Him too we know to have labored diligently, and to have manifested most genuine providence in his oversight of the people, particularly caring for all the poor with liberal hand.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:67
verses.text: In his time we became acquainted with Pamphilus, that most eloquent man, of truly philosophical life, who was esteemed worthy of the office of presbyter in that parish.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:68
verses.text: It would be no small matter to show what sort of a man he was and whence he came.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:69
verses.text: But we have described, in our special work concerning him, all the particulars of his life, and of the school which he established, and the trials which he endured in many confessions during the persecution, and the crown of martyrdom with which he was finally honored.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:70
verses.text: But of all that were there he was indeed the most admirable.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:71
verses.text: Among those nearest our times, we have known Pierius, of the presbyters in Alexandria, and Meletius, bishop of the churches in Pontus,—rarest of men.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:72
verses.text: The first was distinguished for his life of extreme poverty and his philosophic learning, and was exceedingly diligent in the contemplation and exposition of divine things, and in public discourses in the church.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:73
verses.text: Meletius, whom the learned called the "honey of Attica," was a man whom every one would describe as most accomplished in all kinds of learning; and it would be impossible to admire sufficiently his rhetorical skill.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:74
verses.text: It might be said that he possessed this by nature; but who could surpass the excellence of his great experience and erudition in other respects?.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:75
verses.text: For in all branches of knowledge had you undertaken to try him even once, you would have said that he was the most skillful and learned.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:76
verses.text: Moreover, the virtues of his life were not less remarkable.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:77
verses.text: We observed him well in the time of the persecution, when for seven full years he was escaping from its fury in the regions of Palestine.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:78
verses.text: Zambdas received the episcopate of the church of Jerusalem after the bishop Hymenaeus, whom we mentioned a little above.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:79
verses.text: He died in a short time, and Hermon, the last before the persecution in our day, succeeded to the apostolic chair, which has been preserved there until the present time.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:80
verses.text: In Alexandria, Maximus, who, after the death of Dionysius, had been bishop for eighteen years, was succeeded by Theonas.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:81
verses.text: In his time Achillas, who had been appointed a presbyter in Alexandria at the same time with Pierius, became celebrated.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:82
verses.text: He was placed over the school of the sacred faith, and exhibited fruits of philosophy most rare and inferior to none, and conduct genuinely evangelical.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:83
verses.text: After Theonas had held the office for nineteen years, Peter received the episcopate in Alexandria, and was very eminent among them for twelve entire years.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:84
verses.text: Of these he governed the church less than three years before the persecution, and for the remainder of his life he subjected himself to a more rigid discipline and cared in no secret manner for the general interest of the churches.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:85
verses.text: On this account he was beheaded in the ninth year of the persecution, and was adorned with the crown of martyrdom.

verses.name: Eusebius: Chuch History Book VII 32:86
verses.text: Having written out in these books the account of the successions from the birth of our Saviour to the destruction of the places of worship,—a period of three hundred and five years,—permit me to pass on to the contests of those who, in our day, have heroically fought for religion, and to leave in writing, for the information of posterity, the extent and the magnitude of those conflicts.
